displayed_text: Patient: I put high marks because I understand because we trust… Doctor: Well I’m glad you understand because otherwise – otherwise you’re not gonna do what’s good for you. Patient: You’re right and I listen. You listen to me and I… Doctor: You sure do listen. Yeah. Patient: That’s what I like about everything. Doctor: So I’m going to give you three scripts. Okay. One for the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The new one and then the OxyContin and then uh your Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now what’s going on with your Zometa and everything? That’s XGEVA is B___ doing that?

Healthcare Professional: Yes. Doctor: his counts are already up and ready for the next cycle, that’s the safest. Family Member: Oh, got it. Got it. Yep, I see that. I see that. Math makes sense. Yep. Family Member: Now, I just have to remember it. (pause) Patient: We’ll see, we’ll just try to make it happen. We’ll just schedule it out. Family Member: Mmm. I think we might go with the artificial, artificial tree. Aren’t we glad we Doctor: So, I, um, setup an appointment for you to come in at two weeks to, uh, (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, that way, it’s known. It can’t, you know, fall through the cracks, related to your shots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The chemo will be sorta mixed in there. Uh, and if it’s one week here or there because when you choose to start your chemo, we can move that shot. Uh, I just put that in as a placeholder so that we know when you have a shot, so we don’t miss that. Family Member: So, um, we’ve had a little bit of a (pause)

Family Member: So he’ll go downstairs and get his blood drawn. Doctor: Yes. All right. So let me make a copy of this though for you for your records. Family Member: We’re very thankful for meeting you. And how thorough you are. And how comfortable, you make you know, it makes me feel comfortable. Doctor: Thank you. Thank you. I always tell me I'm not happy that we met under the circumstances- Patient: Yes. Doctor: - but try make the best of it. Family Member: Yes, yes. And your knowledge you know. You have so much knowledge, you know, different trials and medicines Doctor: You'll help me, you know my family is not in medicine. Family Member: Oh really? Doctor: But sometimes I get accused of speaking in too much medical lingo. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So if you don't, because a lot of my friends are doctors obviously.

Patient: So where would the poop bag be, doc? Doctor: One on one side. One on the other side. Patient: Oh, doc! That ain’t – ohhhh, doc! That’s a stanky situation, doc! Doctor: I – pfffff – this is why I know you, Mr. L_! Patient: Oh, man! Doctor: I know you’re not gonna jump into this. Let me tell you this. I know you. Patient: Oh, man! Doctor: When push comes to shove, and this is reeeeaaaalllly bad. Patient: Doc, I was just talkin’ about the piss bag. Doctor: I know, but your other problem is the poop! Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Even if you re-route the piss bag, you may not be able to get away from not re-routing the poop. It just depends.

Family Member: it’s radium for sure? Doctor: Well, it’s radium as an option. You know, you guys might look at that and go um, I don’t know how I feel about it and after you talk to the radiation doctor who administers it, you know, some people might say oh, gosh, I just worried about it and I’d rather take chemo and that’s okay too. I’m just trying to make it so easy. I mean any and all of this is interchangeable. If you had just bone only, you could get chemo Patient: Okay. Doctor: but if you have not just bone you can’t get radium. So, radium is only good for one thing. You got bone you can get radium. Patient: Radium. Doctor: It can’t go anywhere else. So, if it’s anywhere else other than bone, no go on the radium. Taxotere, you know, chemo could be anywhere anytime, less picky. Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes.

Patient: I thought, I’ve been thinking about chemo. Doctor: Yeah, I appreciate you thinking about it because I think it warrants Patient: Right. Doctor: thinking about you know. So, there’s standard chemo which is the Taxotere that we chatted about which is that once every three weeks for over an hour. Um the studies that we had talked about there’s probably only one that you’re eligible for which is the chemo plus/minus the high-dose vitamin C but that is a pretty intensive treatment where you’re here twice a week Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: for the whole duration. Yeah, so that’s, in talking to you about that last time Patient: Right. Doctor: that’s just too time consuming especially based on where you guys live and so on. Um but, in reviewing your scans it looks like it’s just all in your bones and not thank goodness in the organs or anywhere else. So, there is a liquid radiation that’s available for patients who have, Healthcare Professional: No its okay, I decided to come on in here. Doctor: We were just talking about radium um which is that liquid radiation that only patients who have stuff in their bones not liver or anywhere else would kind of be the right patient to get that medication and that’s like a one-minute injection that the radiation oncology doctors did once a month Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they do that six months so once a month for six months and that’s been shown to help people live longer and that’s actually FDA approved. So, one could run that through the insurance, you know get treated, and be on your way. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream – Patient: Okay, but -- Doctor: To get control. We’re fixing it here, but the rest of you is not controlled. Doctor: Okay? Hi!!! Patient: So. So. Doctor: We’re having all sorts of discussion! Healthcare Professional 2: Really?

Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh… Doctor: I think you might need surgery to fix that problem. Patient: A surgeon? Doctor: Yeah a urologist. Patient: That sounds like fun. laughs]] Doctor: I know. Laughs]] Well it’s better than constantly dealing with this pestering problem. Family Member: The pestering is what it is. Doctor: Yeah, you shouldn’t just sit on it. Family Member: That’s what I told him, I said it’s gonna fall off if you don’t do something. Laughs]] Doctor: No I don’t think, no but the things way more… Patient: Are we on tape right now? Ah, we’ll talk about that later. Doctor: No but I’m surprised, how many months have you been putting up with this? A lot of time? Like years? Family Member: No, no. Six months, eight months?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I’ll tell him about you though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But he’s coming May ninth. Patient: Alright. Don’t you leave me yet man. (Laughs) Doctor: I hope so too. He’s the man right? Patient: Yeah, yeah you’re the man but you have more grey. <____> refer me to you. Doctor: I hope that when I see you next time I will be able to give you news that yes he’s coming. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so, so we do this blood test all the way up until September. Doctor: Oh we’re still gonna do the blood test. I still get blood tests.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once once you decide, if you decide to participate in the clinical trial, then you will come back and there will be a screening visit. Or uh we’re going to go through all the eligibility with you. Do a physical exam, go through a CT scan and a bone scan. It’s a little bit more involved. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um if you decide the trial doesn’t sound right for you, then I am going to start the standard Xtandi and we’re going to send it up, send the medication to you house hopefully after its reimbursed. Patient: Right. Patient: No. Uh uh. Oh, you all gon’ call me today or tomorrow about the blood work, right? Doctor: As soon as I have your PSA test which either be uh late this afternoon or early tomorrow morning, I’m going to call you at the (doc recites patient’s telephone number) Patient: Right. Doctor: Phone number. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Is is that the best for you? Patient: Yes. Mhm.

Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging.

Family Member: So, um, we’ve had a little bit of a (pause) Doctor: So, so, well, here, here’s - I have lack of flexibility. So, again, I can only see you on Tuesdays. Family Member: Got it. Doctor: Okay? So, again, unless we give you the chemo on the same day, but it’s going to be Wednesday or Thursday. Um. And, again, most people are not under the bed. Most, unless you, you are puking your guts out which is pretty rare. Most people are just, sort of, feel like that they’ve, um - “I—I- I gotta go take a nap.” Family Member: Yeah, that’s what T_ said. Doctor: So, I- I--I am just gonna go take a nap. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s not bad. There’s nothing wrong with ya. You know, if you’re achy- Patient: Just tired. Doctor: Just ‘cuz, you know, you’re just take a couple of Advil, and you just say, “I, I gotta go take a nap.” Most people don’t notice much. Uh, just like, “Okay, they told me I’d feel it this weekend.” Uh. Family Member: Okay! Doctor: Most people really just lose the end of their day. You know, they’re at work, work, work, and they just sorta say, “Oh.” And they’re toast. Patient: And when the end of the day is all over, you nap.

Patient: the mountains the desert everything. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I understand what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah I can only express my concern. Patient: And I got emergency stops that I can hit it… Doctor: Okay. When are you going? Doctor: You want to wait until we know if this medicine does well or you go first and then we start the medicine? Patient: Ooooh I wanted to go to the F___. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re having, my church is having a bike blessing on the twenty fourth. Doctor: Of? Patient: Of this month. Doctor: Oh, okay, fine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in the past you know we talked about the backup plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: What will we do - the day that I say hey, you know this isn’t working or you say I don’t want to do this anymore. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, We checked, you know, the one, the new therapy setting still where you live at. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Some of it is sometimes that blood test that’s fluctuating could be better. Usually it doesn’t. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we would definitely have to repeat that again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because if you’re seven and remained positive, then you’re eligible for one study versus another study. Patient: Oh.

Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours. Doctor: hm mmm, yep, yeah, Do you feel like you empty when you pee Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or do you feel there’s a little more in there? Patient: There’s more because you go ahead and pee the full stream then you stop then you, it’s bogged down. Doctor: Yep, Yep, So, do me a favor. Like after seven p.m. at night don’t drink fluid; Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race
